p: Glechoma hederacea L., more commonly known as ground ivy, is a perennial herb with creeping stem that can be found throughout Northern Europe and the neighboring regions of Asia. The aerial parts of the plant (consumed as salad or tea) have been used in both Asian and European traditional medicine as a remedy for several digestive, pulmonary, skeletal, and inflammatory conditions [ 153]. Active components include several polyphenols such as chlorogenic acid, caffeic acid, ferulic acid, rutin, genistin, rosmarinic acid, quercetin, or genistein [ 153] and triterpenoids such as ursolic acid and oleanoic acid [ 154, 155]. Additionally, studies report that G. hederacea leaves contain polyunsaturated fatty acids [ 156] and a type of insecticidal lectin called Gleheda [ 157].
